1092895515157688323.text: I may be way off base here! It just seems like the common narrative that we need to imbue $ETH with a monetary quality by arbitrary requiring it for transaction fees is not critical and actually complicates the security model for PoS. Plus its just bad UX!

1092895514595639299.text: We can have a fixed supply fee token which has intuitive SoV properties or just pay network fees with a stable coin like DAI.

1092895513907814400.text: Since this valuation model does not depend on $ETH being used to pay for transaction fees, we can specify any asset we want to use for this purpose. This asset's monetary policy can be optimized independently to make it a more useful currency.

1092895513232531458.text: We can apply a DCF analysis based on the risks of staking and the expected returns from transaction and storage fees. By setting fees correctly we can target a given amount of security for all applications on the platform and increase or decrease as needed.

1092895512460701701.text: Luckily, valuation models based on future transaction and storage fees are much more intuitive than the nebulous valuation models of speculative currencies/commodities.

1092895511701606406.text: If we want to create a reliably secure platform, we need to assess the desired level of security and modulate transaction and storage fees in order to target a specific amount of value deposited by stakers.

1092895510921396225.text: Therefore the platform's security requirement is not coupled to the market cap of $ETH--and it's dangerous to make the assumption that as the value of $ETH increases or decreases, that the network will adjust and provide the correct level of security.

1092895510233563136.text: Perhaps the value of $ETH will always be larger than any individual token, but it would be incredibly surprising if the aggregate value of assets secured by the platform doesn't rapidly outpace that of $ETH.

1092895509470216192.text: The maker economy could become massive and the value of $MKR which is rooted in stability fees could conceivably be larger than that of $ETH.

1092895508769792000.text: There are use cases which have tremendous value potential but low transaction and storage overhead. Maker is a good example.

1092895507993776129.text: This should be obvious in the sense that the valuation of $ETH is rooted in the transaction fees and (perhaps in the future) storage fees of maintaining a distributed ledger.

1092895507243040775.text: Right now the value of $ETH dwarfs that of tokens that exist on the platform, but if the platform delivers on its promise that is unlikely to be the case for ever.

1092895506584518657.text: These variables are hard to estimate and are likely to change drastically as the platform matures, scalability improvements will result in higher network capacity and all else equal reduce the value of $ETH as a commodity.

1092895505775030272.text: This feels incredibly fragile! If we attempt to value $ETH as a commodity, we need to understand the velocity at which it circulates and we need to understand the transactional capacity of the network.

1092895504931999747.text: Some people see this preferential treatment of $ETH as a moat, which results in it being treated (and valued) as a commodity money, and that if this moat ever breaks then value of $ETH will collapse and proof of stake will fail...

1092895504260874240.text: But this creates friction, meta-transactions are inherently less efficient than transacting natively--And every participant in the protocol would benefit from native transaction accounting to be done in a stable value token.

1092895503585603586.text: We can push economic abstraction to Layer2 with meta transactions if necessary, and we can rely on wallet providers to convert in the UI the cost to perform a transaction from ETH to fiat.

1092895502696435712.text: Yes there is a relationship between the value of $ETH and the cost to attack the network. But if we commit to bad UX as an engineering necessity then we are unlikely to ever deliver a platform that is broadly useful.

1092895501970825217.text: I find it incredibly dissonant for $ETH supporters to simultaneously be excited by the amazing UX improvement of xdai, but then say economic abstraction is a terrible idea.

1092895501198995461.text: Change my View: Depending on a commodity/money valuation model to determine security level of a proof of stake protocol is a mistake and economic abstraction is good for both UX and security of PoS. Thread

982499357751742465.text: 15/ Generally speaking deciding if updates should be opt-in or opt-out is interesting and the correct approach depends on use-case. my personal take: base-layer blockchain protocols (opt-in), DAOs (opt-out), decentralized exchanges (opt-out), wallets (opt-in)

982499356476674048.text: 14/ Obviously this places more of a burden on the user to ensure that their funds remain safe than a model where they have to explicitly opt-in to each update, personally in the case of 0x this feels worth it in exchange for greater liquidity.

982499355222560768.text: 13/ As an aside it would  be *really* useful to have a service which allows you to subscribe to specific functions being called on smart contracts and get a push notification...

982499353968472065.text: 12/ On the flipside, what happens if an update is done maliciously? If *atleast one* user is paying attention they can alert everyone else, who can easily independently verify that users claims and choose to withdraw their funds prior to the update.

982499352747880448.text: 11/ In the case of 0x, this drop-off (even if users are just slow to update but eventually do) is particularly concerning because it reduces the general utility of the protocol each time there is an update. If you assume most updates will be beneficial this is clearly bad UX.

982499351518949381.text: 10/ How do you deliver updates? You can either push updates to users or require users to opt-in to updates. If you require users to opt-in you should expect a significant amount of drop-off where users don't update even though they probably should...

982499350210338820.text: 9/ Its generally unrealistic to expect any type of software to never need to be upgraded, and in a rapidly evolving ecosystem its reasonable to expect incremental improvements to be made somewhat regularly.

982499348817874944.text: 8/ With sufficient security, the most important feature of an exchange is the trade volume or liquidity. The more people that are actively trading, the more useful it is for everyone participating.

982499347538509825.text: 7/ The 0x protocol makes such a trade-off and if you look at their whitepaper and communication they make a strong argument for why that particular design choice was made.

982499346246709248.text: 6/ This is an important distinction because it means that you do not optimize for trustlessness, but user experience, and there are lots of tradeoffs that make something harder to verify, but on net offer a better user experience.

982499344967524352.text: 5/ IMO systems which make it easier to verify (or less likely to change unexpectedly) are just providing a better user experience, not a *more*  or *less* trustless system.

982499343746945024.text: 4/ In practice this means that each individual user is responsible for choosing how much trust they place is the system and how actively they verify based on their understanding and assumptions system and incentives involved.

982499342186680320.text: 3/ That does not necessarily mean that a system will continue to work in perpetuity if no one actually ever verifies anything, just that it is possible for an individual to verify things are working as expected and publicly prove to others when something goes wrong.

982499340752179200.text: 2/ Personally my expectation is that with a trustless system I don't *have* to trust another party in order to use the system. In other words: don't trust, verify.

931303073666002944.text: 6/ Examples of token models that are not consistent with these assumptions: medium of exchange tokens, dApp fee tokens, equity tokens

931303018921906176.text: 5/ Examples of token models that are consistent with these assumptions: PoW, PoS, Governance tokens, decentralized oracles

931302944862904320.text: 4/ Axiom 3: Mechanisms which require a unique token in order to incentivize and disincentive agents to provide a service will accrue value relative to the service being provided.

931302883471056902.text: 3/ Axiom 2: It is not defensible to force the usage of a token in such a way that the dApp would work equally well or better using a different token. (e.g. ETH or a stable coin)

931302826331873280.text: 2/ Axiom 1: Fees are only justified for services provided by token holders. The execution of arbitrary smart-contract code does not justify paying fees in excess of the gas used to validate/mine transactions.
